Description: Reaction: When the adversary successfully attacks a PC, the GM gains a Fear point.
Passive: Allows the adversary to be put in the spotlight up to X times per GM turn (under normal Fear costs).
Passive: When the adversary successfully attacks, PCs in range lose Hope and/or the GM gains Fear.
Action: Calls additional adversaries to the battlefield, often through the use of Fear or Stress.
Action: A targeted attack or effect that inflicts one or more PCs with a negative condition like Restrained, Vulnerable, or Dizzied.
Action: An attack that affects all targets in a specific area (e.g., "Very Close" or "in a path") instead of a single target.
Passive: Reduces damage taken (often physical) by a fixed amount or halves it.
Reaction: Allows the adversary to make an immediate attack against a creature that has dealt damage to it.
Features that knock back targets or otherwise manipulate their position on the battlefield.
Passive: The adversary requires a round to prepare its action, which is often balanced by powerful abilities.
Passive: The horde's standard damage is reduced to value X once it has lost half or more of its Hit Points.
Action: Allows putting multiple allies in the spotlight alongside itself, often using Fear or Stress.
Passive: The adversary is defeated by any damage. For every X damage a PC deals, an additional minion in range is defeated.
Action: All minions of the same type attack a target with a single, shared attack roll and combine their damage.
A combination of an action to become Hidden and a passive trait that grants bonus damage when attacking from hiding or with advantage.
Abilities that enable fast and often unconventional movement, such as teleporting between shadows or ignoring difficult terrain.
Reaction: When the adversary is defeated, it is replaced by a new stat block (a new phase) with different abilities.
Long-term effects that trigger after a certain number of rounds or in response to player actions and often have devastating impacts.
Action: Grants allies positive effects like damage resistance, condition removal, or other bonuses.
Action: Controls the battlefield (e.g., through thorn vines) or inflicts opponents with negative conditions without primarily dealing damage.
